intro: Acer dasycarpum f. weiri, commonly known as the Weiri maple, is a unique variant of the genus Acer, characterized by its distinct foliage and growth habits. This plant is native to specific regions in China and is valued for its ornamental qualities, particularly its vibrant autumn colors. The leaves are typically palmately lobed, with a serrated margin, and can vary in size depending on environmental conditions. It prefers well-drained soil and partial to full sun, making it suitable for temperate climates. Due to its limited distribution and specific habitat requirements, it is often cultivated in botanical gardens and conservation programs.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acer dasycarpum f. weiri is primarily native to the mountainous regions of central and southern China, particularly in the provinces of Sichuan, Yunnan, and Guizhou. It thrives in temperate climates with high altitudes, often found in forests and shrublands. This plant is commonly associated with rocky and well-drained soils, preferring shady to partially sunny conditions. Its natural habitat includes areas with moderate rainfall and cool temperatures throughout the year. It is an important component of the local flora in these regions.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acer dasycarpum f. weiri was mainly introduced to areas with temperate climates and well-drained soils, particularly in regions with moderate rainfall. It thrives in full sun to partial shade and is commonly found in mountainous or hilly landscapes. This variety is often cultivated for its ornamental value, including its distinctive foliage and autumn coloration. It has been introduced to several countries in Europe and parts of Asia for landscaping and horticultural purposes. Due to its adaptability, it has become a popular choice for urban and suburban gardens.
